home.subtitle: Your interactive journey into the world of modern software engineering.

java.subtitle: The foundation of enterprise software development.

core.title: Core Concepts
core.description: Java is a high-level, class-based, object-oriented programming language that is designed to have as few implementation dependencies as possible.

platform.title: Platform Independent
platform.content: Write Once, Run Anywhere (WORA) capability via the Java Virtual Machine (JVM).

memory.title: Memory Management
memory.content: Automatic garbage collection handles memory allocation and deallocation.

encapsulation.title: Encapsulation
encapsulation.content: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit.

inheritance.title: Inheritance
inheritance.content: Mechanism where a new class derives properties and characteristics from an existing class.

polymorphism.title: Polymorphism
polymorphism.content: Ability of an object to take on many forms, allowing for flexible and reusable code.

streams.title: Streams API
streams.description: Process sequences of elements declaratively with functional-style operations.

microservices.title: Microservices Architecture
microservices.subtitle: Decoupling applications into small, independent services.

whatIs.title: What are Microservices?
whatIs.content: Microservices architecture is an approach to building a single application as a suite of small services, each running in its own process and communicating with lightweight mechanisms, often an HTTP resource API.

decentralized.title: Decentralized Data
decentralized.content: Each service manages its own database, ensuring loose coupling but requiring eventual consistency patterns.

smartEndpoints.title: Smart Endpoints
smartEndpoints.content: Services communicate via simple REST APIs or messaging queues (RabbitMQ, Kafka), keeping logic in the services, not the pipes.

automated.title: Automated Deployment
automated.content: Requires robust CI/CD pipelines to manage the complexity of deploying multiple services.

gateway.title: API Gateway
gateway.content: A server that is the single entry point into the system. It encapsulates the internal system architecture and provides an API that is tailored to each client.

circuitBreaker.title: Circuit Breaker
circuitBreaker.content: Prevents an application from repeatedly trying to execute an operation that's likely to fail. Essential for resilience in distributed systems.

discovery.title: Service Discovery
discovery.content: Automatic detection of devices and services offered by these devices on a computer network. Tools like Eureka or Consul are commonly used.

opinionated.title: Opinionated
opinionated.content: It takes an opinionated view of the Spring platform and third-party libraries so you can get started with minimum fuss.

standalone.title: Standalone
standalone.content: Create stand-alone Spring applications that you can just run (embedded Tomcat, Jetty, or Undertow).

production.title: Production Ready
production.content: Provides production-ready features such as metrics, health checks, and externalized configuration.

quickStart.title: Quick Start
quickStart.desc: A simple REST Controller in Spring Boot.

entryPoint.title: The Entry Point
entryPoint.desc: Bootstrapping the application is as simple as annotating a class.

di.title: Dependency Injection
di.content: Spring's core feature. It allows you to decouple the creation of objects from their usage.

jpa.title: Spring Data JPA
jpa.content: Makes it easy to implement JPA based repositories. It reduces the boilerplate code required to access data.

security.title: Spring Security
security.content: A powerful and highly customizable authentication and access-control framework.

dockerK8s.title: Docker & Kubernetes
dockerK8s.subtitle: Containerization and Orchestration for modern apps.

docker.title: Docker
docker.content: Docker packages software into standardized units called containers that have everything the software needs to run including libraries, system tools, code, and runtime.

k8s.title: Kubernetes
k8s.content: Kubernetes (K8s) is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

terminal.title: Interactive Terminal
terminal.desc: Try out some common commands directly in the browser.
terminal.welcome: Welcome to the Interactive Container Lab.
terminal.hint: Try running "docker ps" or "kubectl get pods". Type "help" for more.

images.title: Images
images.content: A read-only template with instructions for creating a Docker container.

pods.title: Pods
pods.content: The smallest deployable units of computing that you can create and manage in Kubernetes.

services.title: Services
services.content: An abstract way to expose an application running on a set of Pods as a network service.

dockerfile.title: Dockerfile
dockerfile.content: A text document that contains all the commands a user could call on the command line to assemble an image.

compose.title: Docker Compose
compose.content: A tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications.

architecture.title: K8s Architecture
architecture.content: Master Node (Control Plane) manages Worker Nodes where Pods run.

databases.title: Databases
databases.subtitle: SQL vs NoSQL: Choosing the right tool for the job.

postgres.title: PostgreSQL (SQL)
postgres.content: A powerful, open source object-relational database system with over 30 years of active development.

mongo.title: MongoDB (NoSQL)
mongo.content: A source-available cross-platform document-oriented database program. Classified as a NoSQL database program, MongoDB uses JSON-like documents.

sqlExample.title: SQL Example
sqlExample.desc: Defining a schema and inserting data in PostgreSQL.

acid.title: ACID Properties
acid.content: Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability. Guarantees validity of database transactions.

cap.title: CAP Theorem
cap.content: Consistency, Availability, Partition Tolerance. A distributed data store can only provide two of the three guarantees.

indexing.title: Indexing
indexing.content: A data structure technique used to quickly locate and access the data in a database.

sqlCard.desc: Relational databases based on structured tables and strict schemas. Ideal for complex relationships and transactional integrity.

nosqlCard.desc: Non-relational databases with flexible schemas. Designed for high performance, massive scale, and rapid development.

interactive.title: Database Playground
interactive.desc: Explore database concepts. Try "help" to see available commands.

schema.title: Schema
schema.sql: Rigid. Must be defined before inserting data.
schema.nosql: Dynamic. Can change at any time.

fedora.title: Fedora Workstation
fedora.subtitle: The premier open source development platform.

why.title: Why Fedora?
why.content: Fedora Workstation is a polished, easy to use, and complete operating system for laptops and desktops, with a complete set of tools for developers and makers of all kinds.

upstream.title: Upstream First
upstream.content: Fedora contributes directly to upstream projects. You get the latest features first.

technologies.title: Leading Edge
technologies.content: First to adopt new technologies like Wayland, PipeWire, and Btrfs by default.

containers.title: Container Ready
containers.content: Best-in-class support for Podman, Buildah, and Skopeo out of the box.

setup.title: Developer Setup
setup.desc: Essential commands to get your environment ready.

systemd.title: Systemd
systemd.content: A suite of basic building blocks for a Linux system. It provides a system and service manager that runs as PID 1 and starts the rest of the system.

firewall.title: Firewalld
firewall.content: A firewall management tool that provides a dynamically managed firewall with support for network/firewall zones.

toolbox.title: Toolbox
toolbox.content: Offers a familiar package-based environment for developing and debugging software that runs fully unprivileged using Podman.

docker.title: Docker
docker.subtitle: Containerization Mastery
docker.description: The complete guide to containerization, from basic concepts to production-grade orchestration.

quiz.perfect: Perfect score! You're a Docker master!
quiz.goodEffort: Good effort! Review the sections and try again.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between a Docker Image and a Container?
options: An image is a running instance, a container is the blueprint
An image is a read-only template, a container is a runnable instance
Containers are for Linux, Images are for Windows

questions.question: Which command lists all running containers?
What is the purpose of a multi-stage build?
options: To run multiple apps in one container
To reduce final image size by discarding build dependencies

terminal.welcome: Welcome to the Docker Interactive Shell
terminal.hint: Try commands like 'docker ps', 'docker images', or 'docker run hello-world'

sections.whatIsDockerDesc: Docker is an open platform for developing, shipping, and running applications. It enables you to separate your applications from your infrastructure so you can deliver software quickly.
sections.whyContainersDesc: Containers are lightweight, standalone, executable packages of software that include everything needed to run an application: code, runtime, system tools, system libraries and settings.
sections.theDaemonDesc: The background process that manages Docker objects such as images, containers, networks, and volumes. It listens for Docker API requests.
sections.theClientDesc: The primary way many Docker users interact with Docker. When you use commands like `docker run`, the client sends these commands to dockerd.
sections.registriesDesc: Stores Docker images. Docker Hub is a public registry that anyone can use, and Docker is configured to look for images on Docker Hub by default.
sections.namespacesDesc: Docker uses a technology called namespaces to provide the isolated workspace called the container. When you run a container, Docker creates a set of namespaces for that container.
sections.ipcNamespace: ipc: Managing access to IPC resources
sections.utsNamespace: uts: Isolating kernel and version identifiers
sections.controlGroupsDesc: A Linux kernel feature that limits, accounts for, and isolates the resource usage (CPU, memory, disk I/O, network, etc.) of a collection of processes.
sections.cgroupsExample: Example: Limiting a container to 50% CPU and 512MB RAM.
sections.useMultiStageDesc: Keep image sizes down by copying only necessary artifacts to the final image.
sections.leverageBuildCacheDesc: Order instructions from least to most frequently changing (e.g., copy package.json before source code).
sections.useDockerignoreDesc: Exclude unnecessary files (node_modules, git, logs) from the build context.
sections.dontRunAsRootDesc: Always create a non-root user in your Dockerfile and switch to it using the `USER` instruction.
sections.useTrustedBaseImagesDesc: Stick to official images from Docker Hub or verified publishers. Avoid `latest` tag in production.
sections.scanForVulnerabilitiesDesc: Use tools like `docker scan` or Trivy to check your images for known security flaws.
sections.dockerComposeDesc: Compose is a tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications. With Compose, you use a YAML file to configure your application's services.
sections.servicesDesc: The computing resources of your application (e.g., web server, database).
sections.networksDesc: Define how services communicate. By default, Compose sets up a single network for your app.
sections.volumesDesc: Persistent data storage. Essential for databases so data survives container restarts.
sections.tryDockerCommands: Try running some Docker commands in this simulated environment.

kubernetes.title: Kubernetes
kubernetes.subtitle: Orchestration
kubernetes.description: Scale, manage, and automate your containerized applications with the industry-standard orchestrator.

quiz.goodTry: Good try! Review the concepts and try again.

questions.question: What is the smallest deployable unit in Kubernetes?
Which component ensures a specified number of pod replicas are running?
How do you expose an application running on a set of Pods?

terminal.welcome: Welcome to the Kubernetes Interactive Shell
terminal.hint: Try commands like 'kubectl get pods', 'kubectl get nodes', or 'kubectl cluster-info'

sections.podDesc: The smallest deployable unit. A Pod represents a single instance of a running process in your cluster. It can contain one or more containers.
sections.nodeDesc: A worker machine in Kubernetes. A node may be a VM or physical machine, depending on the cluster. Each node is managed by the Control Plane.
sections.clusterDesc: A set of node machines for running containerized applications. If you're running Kubernetes, you're running a cluster.
sections.apiServerDesc: The front end for the Kubernetes control plane. It exposes the Kubernetes API.
sections.etcdDesc: Consistent and highly-available key value store used as Kubernetes' backing store for all cluster data.
sections.schedulerDesc: Watches for newly created Pods with no assigned node, and selects a node for them to run on.
sections.controllerManagerDesc: Runs controller processes (Node controller, Job controller, EndpointSlice controller, etc.).
sections.deploymentsDesc: A Deployment provides declarative updates for Pods and ReplicaSets. You describe a desired state in a Deployment, and the Deployment Controller changes the actual state to the desired state at a controlled rate.
sections.statefulSetDesc: Manages the deployment and scaling of a set of Pods, and provides guarantees about the ordering and uniqueness of these Pods. Ideal for databases.
sections.daemonSetDesc: Ensures that all (or some) Nodes run a copy of a Pod. As nodes are added to the cluster, Pods are added to them. Useful for log collectors or monitoring agents.
sections.clusterIPDesc: Exposes the Service on a cluster-internal IP. Choosing this value makes the Service only reachable from within the cluster. (Default)
sections.nodePortDesc: Exposes the Service on each Node's IP at a static port. You can contact the NodePort Service, from outside the cluster, by requesting NodeIP:NodePort.
sections.loadBalancerDesc: Exposes the Service externally using a cloud provider's load balancer.
sections.configMapsDesc: API object used to store non-confidential data in key-value pairs. Pods can consume ConfigMaps as environment variables, command-line arguments, or as configuration files in a volume.
sections.secretsDesc: Object that contains a small amount of sensitive data such as a password, a token, or a key. Using a Secret means you don't need to include confidential data in your application code.
sections.persistentVolumeDesc: A piece of storage in the cluster that has been provisioned by an administrator or dynamically provisioned using Storage Classes.
sections.persistentVolumeClaimDesc: A request for storage by a user. It is similar to a Pod. Pods consume node resources and PVCs consume PV resources.
sections.practiceKubectl: Practice your kubectl commands in this simulated environment.

git.title: Git
git.subtitle: Version Control
git.description: Master distributed version control with Git - the industry standard for tracking code changes and collaborating with teams.

quiz.goodEffort: Good effort! Review the sections and try again.

questions.question: What command stages all changes for commit?
How do you create and switch to a new branch in one command?
What does 'git rebase' do?
options: Reapplies commits on top of another base tip

terminal.welcome: Welcome to the Git Interactive Shell
terminal.hint: Try commands like 'git status', 'git log', or 'git branch'

sections.repositoryDesc: A directory containing your project and its version history.
sections.commitDesc: A snapshot of your repository at a specific point in time.
sections.workingDirectoryDesc: The files in your project you're currently working on.
sections.stagingAreaDesc: Files that are ready to be committed.
sections.whyBranchDesc: Branching allows you to diverge from the main line of development and continue to work without messing with that main line. It's essential for:
sections.fastForwardMergeDesc: When there's a direct path from the current branch tip to the target branch, Git simply moves the pointer forward. No merge commit is created.
sections.threeWayMergeDesc: When branches have diverged, Git creates a new merge commit that combines the changes from both branches. This preserves the history of both branches.
sections.rebaseDesc: Reapply commits on top of another base tip. Creates a linear history but rewrites commit hashes. Never rebase public commits!
sections.cherryPickDesc: Apply a specific commit from one branch to another. Useful for selectively applying bug fixes or features.
sections.bisectDesc: Binary search through commit history to find which commit introduced a bug. Extremely powerful for debugging.
sections.featureBranchWorkflowDesc: Feature development in a dedicated branch instead of the main branch.
sections.createBranch: Create a new branch from main
sections.makeCommits: Make commits on the feature branch
sections.pushBranch: Push the feature branch to remote
sections.gitflowWorkflowDesc: A strict branching model designed around the project release.

github.title: GitHub
github.subtitle: Collaboration
github.description: The world's leading platform for version control and collaboration. Build, ship, and maintain software with millions of developers.

quiz.goodTry: Good try! Review the concepts and try again.

questions.question: What is a Pull Request?
options: A proposal to merge changes from one branch to another
A way to delete a repository

questions.question: What does GitHub Actions allow you to do?
options: Automate workflows like CI/CD, testing, and deployments

questions.question: What is a GitHub Issue used for?

terminal.welcome: Welcome to the GitHub CLI Interactive Shell
terminal.hint: Try commands like 'gh pr list', 'gh issue list', or 'gh repo view'

pullRequests.title: Pull Requests & Code Review
pullRequests.prWorkflowDescription: Pull Requests let you tell others about changes you've pushed to a branch in a repository on GitHub. Once a PR is opened, you can discuss and review the potential changes with collaborators.

constructive.title: Be Constructive
constructive.description: Provide specific, actionable feedback. Focus on the code, not the person. Suggest improvements rather than just pointing out problems.

promptly.title: Review Promptly
promptly.description: Timely reviews keep the development process moving. Aim to review PRs within 24 hours to maintain team momentum.

thoroughly.title: Test Thoroughly
thoroughly.description: Don't just read the code—pull it down and test it. Verify that changes work as expected and don't break existing functionality.

githubActions.title: GitHub Actions & CI/CD
githubActions.whatAreActionsDescription: GitHub Actions makes it easy to automate all your software workflows with world-class CI/CD. Build, test, and deploy your code right from GitHub.

workflows.title: Workflows
workflows.description: Automated processes defined in YAML files that run on specific events.

jobs.title: Jobs
jobs.description: A set of steps that execute on the same runner. Jobs can run in parallel or sequentially.

actions.title: Actions
actions.description: Reusable units of code that can be shared across workflows and repositories.

ci.title: Continuous Integration
ci.description: Automatically build and test code changes. Run tests on every push or PR to catch bugs early.

cd.title: Continuous Deployment
cd.description: Automatically deploy to staging or production when code is merged. Streamline your release process.

issuesAndProjectManagement.title: Issues & Project Management
issuesAndProjectManagement.githubIssuesDescription: Issues are a great way to keep track of tasks, enhancements, and bugs for your projects. They're like email—except they can be shared and discussed with the rest of your team.
issuesAndProjectManagement.githubProjectsDescription: Projects help you organize and prioritize your work. You can create project boards for specific features, comprehensive roadmaps, or even release checklists.

dependabot.title: Dependabot
dependabot.description: Automatically checks your dependencies for known security vulnerabilities and creates PRs to update them.

codeScanning.title: Code Scanning
codeScanning.description: Finds security vulnerabilities and coding errors in your code. Powered by CodeQL and other tools.

secretScanning.title: Secret Scanning
secretScanning.description: Detects secrets (API keys, tokens) that have been accidentally committed to your repository.

branchProtection.title: Enable Branch Protection
branchProtection.description: Require PR reviews and status checks before merging.

secretsManagement.title: Use Secrets Management
secretsManagement.description: Store sensitive data in GitHub Secrets, never in code.

twoFactorAuth.title: Enable 2FA
twoFactorAuth.description: Protect your account with two-factor authentication.

reviewPermissions.title: Review Permissions
reviewPermissions.description: Regularly audit who has access to your repositories.

sections.practiceGithubCLI: Practice GitHub CLI commands in this simulated environment.

kubernetes.title: Kubernetes
kubernetes.description: The industry standard for container orchestration. Automate deployment, scaling, and management.

sections.controlPlaneDesc: The brain of the cluster (API Server, Scheduler, etc.)
sections.podsDesc: The smallest deployable unit of computing
sections.daemonSetsDesc: Run a copy of a Pod on every node
sections.servicesDesc: Stable network for Pods (ClusterIP, NodePort, LoadBalancer)
sections.practiceKubectl: Practice your kubectl commands in this simulated environment.

terminal.welcome: Welcome to the Kubernetes Interactive Shell
terminal.hint: Try commands like 'kubectl get pods', 'kubectl get nodes', or 'kubectl cluster-info'

quiz.goodTry: Good try! Review the concepts and try again.

questions.question: What is the smallest unit in Kubernetes?
What is a Service used for?
options: To expose an application running on Pods

questions.question: Which component schedules Pods to Nodes?
